In the plane-polar view, orthopyroxene has high relief, shows cleavage, and is pleochroic in pink to green. Cordierite appears clear but, in places, contains conspicuous pleochroic halos (caused by radiation damage) around zircon crystals. Biotite is pleochroic in shades of brown to tan.

In crossed polars, orthopyroxene and cordierite both have 1st-order interference colors. The cordierite, however, contains conspicuous twins that look like twins in plagioclase that pinch out. Biotite has 2nd- to 3rd-order colors, and zircon even higher-order colors. Some of the pleochroic halos around zircon inclusions stand out very well.

16.3.5 Marbles and Related Rocks

In this section, we look at marbles and related rocks. This means we are considering rocks that formed from metasediments that contained significant amounts of carbonate minerals. The protoliths may have been limestones or dolostones consisting only of calcite or dolomite, or marls that contain other minerals besides carbonates. Like metabasites and metapelites, these calcareous rocks develop different minerals at different grades of metamorphism. Chapter 15 discussed all the different minerals that can form. In this chapter we look at photographs of rocks that contain the most common of those minerals. The figure below shows them listed in general order of increasing grade.

Talc, tremolite and phlogopite are hydrous minerals that give way to anhydrous diopside, wollastonite, garnet, and other minerals at high grades. But the minerals that form depend on the composition of the protolith. If the original rock was a limestone that contained no silica, none of these minerals can form. With this caveat in mind, the photos below begin with relatively low-grade marbles and end with high-grade calcsilicate rocks that contain garnet, vesuvianite, and monticellite.

▪Marble

⇒Link to 3D rotatable image of this marble

The marble, seen above in hand specimen and thin section, comes from Lucerne Valley, California, about 80 km northeast of Los Angeles. It contains both calcite and dolomite. The calcite is grayish with a very light blue tinge; the dolomite is lighter-colored – almost white. The two minerals are very difficult to distinguish in hand specimen and in thin section without using a chemical stain.

In the thin-section views, carbonates are the only minerals easily seen. Some of the carbonate grains in the PP view show faintly colored twins. Twins are more easily seen in the XP view. Carbonate interference colors are so high that they are very pastel or appear white in the XP view

▪Marble Containing Graphite and Phlogopite

This marble comes from the western Adirondack Mountains, near Gouverneur, New York. It is mostly calcite, but close examination of the hand specimen reveals a few brown flakes of phlogopite and some silvery specks of graphite. Some marbles contain conspicuous amounts of aluminous metamorphic minerals. This one does not because it formed from metamorphism of a limestone that contained little but calcite. So the chemical components needed to form Al-rich metamorphic minerals were not present.

In the plane-polarized view, calcite is clear and shows twins. Flakes of graphite appear opaque. Some small flakes of phlogopite are present but not easily found (because they have almost no color) without switching back and forth to the crossed-polars view. In crossed polars, the calcite has its usual pastel colors. Phlogopite has up to 2nd-order blue and red interference colors. The graphite is opaque.

▪Phlogopite Marble

This marble, from Tate, Georgia, comprises mostly pink calcite. Darker bands in the rock contain opaque minerals and phlogopite.

In thin section, the plane-polars view reveals mostly clear calcite (some exhibiting twinning) with one large nearly vertical flake of light-greenish phlogopite on the right. A dozen or so high-relief 1-2 mm long grains of prismatic titanite are present – mostly associated with the phlogopite. A few grains of apatite (very hard to discern) and scattered very small grains of an opaque mineral can be seen.

In crossed polars, the calcite has its typical high-order pastel colors. The phlogopite exhibits a pebbly texture and 2nd-order colors.

▪Talc-Tremolite Schist

This talc-tremolite schist comes from the western Adirondack Mountains, near Gouverneur, New York. The hand sample has a very soapy feel, due to talc. A hand lens reveals sheets of talc and needles of tremolite up to 1 or 2 mm across.

In the PP thin-section view, tremolite is clear and talc has a slightly yellowish hue. One large needle and several blocky grains of tremolite are easily seen. The large tremolite grain in the lower right shows a hint of 60-120o cleavage angles (perhaps more easily seen in the XP view).

In crossed polars, tremolite blades/needles have up to 2nd-order yellow interference colors. The blocky tremolite grains have up to 2nd-order red-purple colors. Talc, in places showing a pebbly mica-like texture, displays 3rd-order colors, similar to those of muscovite.

▪Tremolite Marble

The hand sample above is a marble from the western Adirondack Mountains, New York. It contains white calcite and white tremolite. The calcite is massive and fine grained. The tremolite, a bit hard to discern, is in the form of fine needles less than 1 mm across. Some calcsilicate-rocks are nearly entirely made of tremolite; the photo seen here on the right in Figure 16.260, is an example. It contains only radiating aggregates of tremolite crystals.

The thin-section views above are of a different marble – not the same one seen in hand sample. In the plane-polars view, calcite has high relief, and twinning is apparent in most grains. Tremolite crystals are lower relief, in the form of blades or needles. End views of tremolite crystals have a diamond shape and display 60-120o cleavage angles. A few specks of an opaque mineral can be seen.

In crossed polars, tremolite blades/needles have up to 2nd-order blue and yellow interference colors; end views display 3rd-order colors. Calcite displays its typical high-order pastel interference colors.

▪Forsterite Marble

The hand sample seen in the photo above comes from near Loch Duich in western Scotland. The forsterite appears as pale green crystals that, when present, are sometimes hard to distinguish from diopside in marbles.

The thin-section views are of a different forsterite marble (from Parone, Italy). The forsterite appears as high-relief rounded grains, some quite fractured, in the plane-polarized view. The clear grains around the forsterite are all calcite, some showing a hint of twinning in the PP view. A significant amount of unidentified opaque mineral grains are also present.

In crossed polars, the forsterite has up to high 2nd-order interference colors. The twinned calcite displays high-order but hard to see pastel hues.

▪Forsterite-Diopside Marble

The hand sample seen above is the same as the one in Figure 15.3. It is a forsterite marble from Baffin Island, Canada. Besides light-green forsterite, it also contains lesser amounts of dark-green diopside.

In the plane-polarized view, the pyroxene grains are nearly clear, perhaps slightly greenish, and display well-developed cleavage. One millimeter-sized grain just below and left of the center of the view shows pyroxenes near-90o cleavage angle well. Calcite and olivine grains are nearly clear too, but calcite displays easily seen twinning in two directions. High-relief olivine grains are well-rounded, lack cleavage and stand out above the calcite. Some of the olivine has a faint gray color compared with the other minerals. The tremolite-rock seen above in Figure 16.260 is another example of a calcsilicate rock devoid of carbonate.

In crossed polars both the diopside and olivine have 2nd-order interference colors. The diopside has slightly greater birefringence and colors get to upper 2nd-order. Because of its very high birefringence, calcite’s interference colors cannot be easily seen.

▪Diopside Marble

The photo on the left above is a diopside-bearing marble from Cascade Slide, in New York’s Adirondack Mountains. This marble is in a block of calcsilicate rock, partially covered, that is included within anorthosite. The exposed portion of the calcsilicate rock is about 150 m long and 20 m wide (Baillieul, 1976). This is a typical diopside marble containing green diopside crystals up to 2 mm across surrounded by white calcite.

The thin-section views above show diopside (high relief, near 90o cleavage angles) and calcite (with twins visible in both the PP and XP views). In the XP view, the diopside crystal that shows two cleavages displays minimum interference colors (gray). The other diopside crystal, that is viewed perpendicular to its optic axes, displays maximum (2nd-order blue) interference colors. Calcite’s interference colors are pale pastels of high order.

The two thin-section views in Figures 16.270 and 16.271 are of a diopside-bearing marble that contains garnet. This sample, like the previous one, comes from Cascade Slide in the Adirondacks.

The large grain in the upper left of the view, that has near vertical cleavage, is diopside. In the PP view, the diopside is almost clear. The garnet is clear, in blobby/patchy crystals, has no cleavage, but has considerably more relief than the diopside. The low-relief calcite, in the background, is clear but shows twinning. In crossed polars, the diopside displays vivid high 2nd-order interference colors. Calcite’s interference colors are so high-order and washed out that they cannot be easily seen. The garnet is isotropic.

The two thin-section views on the right show a different diopside-bearing marble. This one is from Candoglia, Italy. In the PP view, the diopside has a more pronounced green color than the two diopside rocks described above. The calcite is clear to gray and displays twinning. Several opaque grains are also present. In crossed polars, the diopside displays up to high 2nd-order interference colors. Calcite’s interference colors, as usual, cannot be easily discerned.

▪Garnet-Wollastonite Calcsilicate

Calcsilicate rocks form by contact metamorphism and metasomatism of carbonate-rich protoliths. During this kind of metamorphism, coarsely-crystalline silicates typically replace some or all original carbonate minerals as metasomatism occurs. Unlike the diopside marbles we saw above, the rock seen below contains no calcite, although it surely did prior to metamorphism.

The photo in Figure 16.274 shows a garnet-diopside-wollastonite calcsilicate from the Lewis Mine, a wollastonite mine near Willsboro, New York. Figure 16.277 is a closeup view of the same rock. This classic mineral collecting site provides high-quality samples of calcsilicate rocks containing red andradite garnet, green diopside, and bladed white wollastonite.

The plane-polar and crossed-polar views above are scans that covered most of an entire thin section of a different rock from the Lewis Mine. In the PP view, the garnet has relatively high relief and a light pink color. The diopside is light green. All the clear mineral grains are wollastonite. In the XP view, garnet is isotropic, wollastonite has only up to middle 1st-order interference colors, and the diopside has up to high 2nd-order colors. Note that the two scans contain several (isotropic) holes where mineral grains were plucked during thin-section polishing.

▪Vesuvianite Marble

The photo in Figure 16.278 shows a vesuvianite-bearing marble from the Jeffrey Mine in Val-des-Sources, Quebec. The mine is an open-pit asbestos mine that ceased operations around 2001. Vesuvianite, also called idocrase, is one of a number of Ca-Mg silicate minerals that form in calcsilicate rocks. It typically has the green color seen in the photo above. Crystals are tetragonal and a hint of this is visible in the hand specimen.

The plane-polar and crossed-polar views show a different vesuvianite marble. This one is from Gavorrano, Italy. The vesuvianite is well-fractured and has very high relief compared with the calcite. Twins are apparent in both the plane-polar and crossed-polar views of calcite. Vesuvianite in this thin section shows up to 1st-order gray interference colors, but vesuvianite may display lower-order and sometimes anomalous blue interference colors.

The photos below show two other thin sections containing vesuvianite. The rock seen in Figures 16.281 and 16.282 contains high-relief vesuvianite and two dark-green (nearly black) grains of spinel. These minerals appear to be floating in calcite in the XP view. In crossed polars, the vesuvianite shows zoning and up to 1st-order gray interference colors, the spinel is isotropic, and the calcite shows high-order interference colors and twinning.

Figures 16.283 and 16.284 show a rock that contains andradite (garnet), vesuvianite, and wollastonite. The andradite is light brown in the PP view and isotropic in crossed polars. The vesuvianite is grayish to light green, and somewhat cloudy, in the PP view. It shows very-low 1st order interference colors in the XP view. If you enlarge the photo, you can see some anomalous blue interference color in some vesuvianite grains. Wollastonite in this rock is clear in PP light and some grains show pyroxene cleavage (near 90o), especially one large grain near the lower left corner. In the XP view, the wollastonite shows up to 1st-order yellow interference colors.

▪Monticellite Marble

The monticellite-bearing marble in Figure 16.285 comes from a quarry in Grand Forks, British Columbia. Besides brown monticellite, white dolomite, and white calcite, this metadolomite contains minor dark-colored diopside. A few small grains of diopside can be seen near the lower-left edge of the specimen.

The photos in these figures (16-286 to 16.289) are of the same thin section, but the latter two are six times wider than the first two.

The PP view above (Figure 16.286) shows two large high-relief grains of monticellite surrounded by dolomite and calcite. Monticellite is a member of the olivine group, and like other olivine minerals has no cleavage. The two large grains, however, contain subparallel fractures. In crossed polars, the monticellite shows 1st-order gray interference colors; the surrounding carbonate minerals display high-order pastels. This thin section is a bit thin – normal interference colors for monticellite range up to 1st-order yellow or orange. The photos in Figures 16.287 and 16.288 are of a different part of the same thin section.
